abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Program Development Policy
            Loan (SPDPL) Project is a stand-alone, single-tranche
            development policy loan (DPL) featuring Uruguay's
            social policy response to the economic crisis of 2001 and
            2002, providing support to past and ongoing, structural and
            administrative reforms in the health, education, and social
            protection sectors, in addition to assisting the early
            activities of the new administration in various social
            policy areas. The SPDPL will also lay the foundation for a
            program of future Bank assistance, as outlined in the
            Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for the period FYO5-FY 10,
            in support of the country's social policy programs,
            through multi-sector programmatic DPLs, as well as through
            investment and technical assistance operations. The proposed
            SPDPL will therefore support specific actions to increase
            the efficiency, coverage, and sustainability of
            Uruguay's health, education, and social protection
            sectors and programs. The policy measures supported under
            the SPDPL seek to achieve steeper reduction in poverty
            levels in the aftermath of the crisis, over and above that
            which would have resulted without the supported measures,
            and, improved equity and efficiency of social sector
            expenditures. Given the single-tranche status of the
            project, the associated risks are considered low to
            moderate. Risks of non-compliance with expected actions are
            considered minimal; however, there are important
            sustainability risks, as some of the SPDPL-supported actions
            represent the starting point of reforms that will require
            continuation over time to be effective. These sustainability
            risks can be classified as political, economic, and
            managerial. Risks however, will be mitigated by a continued
            and strong policy dialogue with the Government. Economic and
            financial risks relate to the possibility of potential
            fiscal restrictions that would limit implementation of
            proposed reforms, potential debt sustainability problems,
            and external shocks. These would be mitigated through the
            inclusion of program expenditures in the Government's
            five-year budget, and expectations that the Government will
            maintain a sustainable macroeconomic framework. Finally,
            managerial risks relate to the possible difficulties in
            managing new sectoral programs, and systems because of the
            potential shortage of skilled human resources. This risk
            will be minimized through training provision to Ministries
            and staff at the local levels, (in particular, to the Social
            Security Fund within the new Ministry of Social Development).
